docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: According to Douglas J. Besharov (''End Welfare Lite as We Know It,'' Op-Ed, Aug. 15), the federal government's recent introduction of tougher work requirements is just what states needed to ''address the deeper needs of welfare families.''

headline.main: The Journey From Welfare to Work

docs.abstract: Six letters comment on Douglas J Besharov Aug 15 Op-Ed assessing welfare reform law on its 10th anniversary; Maureen Lane says current policy inhibits ability of people receiving welfare to leave poverty for good; Joel Berg, executive director of New York City Coalition Against Hunger, disputes Besharov's claims that welfare reform has only slightly increased 'additional hardship'; Rachel Gragg and Margy Waller, who work at Center for Community Change, strongly disagree that working families who receive some federal assistance remain 'on welfare'; Joseph J McGovern says programs that Besharov objects to as 'welfare lite' are all that keep low-wage workers from economic ruin; Prof Robert Cherry disagrees with Besharov's opinion of obstacles to leaving welfare; Connie Boyd says Besharov needs to develop some perspective if he begrudges impoverished mothers and their infants federal nutritional support funds; drawing
docs.snippet: To the Editor:     According to Douglas J. Besharov (''End Welfare Lite as We Know It,'' Op-Ed, Aug. 15), the federal government's recent introduction of tougher work requirements is just what states needed to ''address the deeper needs of welfare...

docs.lead_paragraph: The police in Sleepy Hollow remain without a contract despite recent attempts to break the stalemate, which has gone on for more than two years. Although the village and the New York State Union of Police Associations, which represents the officers, entered into arbitration in June, negotiations have continued behind the scenes.

headline.main: Sleepy Hollow Police Talks at an Impasse

docs.abstract: Police in Sleepy Hollow, NY, and New York State Union of Police Assns remain at stalemate after two years of contract talks; police bargaining committee has rejected recent pay increase offer, primarily because it would have required new officers to pay 20 percent of their medical insurance after about four years of service (S)
